questions.question: For a Poisson variate X, P(X = 1) = P(X = 2). The variance of X is:?
In an experiment, positive and negative values are equally likely to occur. The probability of obtaining at most one negative value in five trials is ?

explanations.a: Given: n = 5, p = 1/2 Let X represents number of negative values in 5 trials, therefore X is a binomial random variable. At most 1 negative value means, k can be 0 and 1 P(At most one negative value) = P(X≤1) -> P(X ≤ 1) = P(X = 0) + P(X = 1)= 1/32 + 5/32= 6/32.
explanations.b: Given: n = 5, p = 1/2 Let X represents number of negative values in 5 trials, therefore X is a binomial random variable. At most 1 negative value means, k can be 0 and 1 P(At most one negative value) = P(X≤1) -> P(X ≤ 1) = P(X = 0) + P(X = 1)= 1/32 + 5/32= 6/32.
explanations.c: Given: n = 5, p = 1/2 Let X represents number of negative values in 5 trials, therefore X is a binomial random variable. At most 1 negative value means, k can be 0 and 1 P(At most one negative value) = P(X≤1) -> P(X ≤ 1) = P(X = 0) + P(X = 1)= 1/32 + 5/32= 6/32.
explanations.d: Given: n = 5, p = 1/2 Let X represents number of negative values in 5 trials, therefore X is a binomial random variable. At most 1 negative value means, k can be 0 and 1 P(At most one negative value) = P(X≤1) -> P(X ≤ 1) = P(X = 0) + P(X = 1)= 1/32 + 5/32= 6/32.

questions.question: For a given biased coin, the probability that the outcome of a toss is a head is 0.4. This coin is tossed 1,000 times. Let X denote the random variable whose value is the number of times that head appeared in these 1,000 tosses. The standard deviation of X is?
